componenttext: Question on risk-adjusted margin. You've been talking about maintaining that risk-adjusted margin. I know it went up this quarter. As we look forward, should we expect that we're going to hold where we are today? Or does that come down somewhat?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Betsy, what I see is it honing in around 2.9% to 3.1%. And I think if you go back to PNC back in 2005 or so, we presented this ratio back then as well, simply because our margin happened to be lower that time. But the cost of credit wasn't there. And I th
componenttext: Betsy, what I see is it honing in around 2.9% to 3.1%. And I think if you go back to PNC back in 2005 or so, we presented this ratio back then as well, simply because our margin happened to be lower that time. But the cost of credit wasn't there. And I think, as people were challenging us to take more credit and interest rate risk, we said we think it's better to look at this on a risk-adjusted basis. And so I think we'll hone in around that 2.9% to 3.1% overall.

componenttext: Yes, of course. I mean I'm pretty certain about the fact that we'll see further decline in net interest income. And I'm more optimistic that we'll continue to see a further decline in credit costs.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Securities portfolio took a big jump this quarter, and your loan demand was down, relatively speaking. And can you just add some color around that? And also, some people in your regions are saying they're starting to see loan demand. And I was wondering i
componenttext: Securities portfolio took a big jump this quarter, and your loan demand was down, relatively speaking. And can you just add some color around that? And also, some people in your regions are saying they're starting to see loan demand. And I was wondering if you can just make any comments about, are you starting to see loan demand in your footprint?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Well, let me comment on the loan demand. I think we've seen, really, it appears to be a bottoming. And I'm talking about loans outside of our distressed book, which we're proactively reducing. But the utilization rate appears to have bottomed. That's been
componenttext: Well, let me comment on the loan demand. I think we've seen, really, it appears to be a bottoming. And I'm talking about loans outside of our distressed book, which we're proactively reducing. But the utilization rate appears to have bottomed. That's been decreasing for three years. And it appears as if the balances are firming up. Now we're not seeing a lot of growth yet, but the interesting thing is we're seeing a lot more activity in the M&A space, the capital markets space, our customers are much more active than they were a year ago. So that's a good sign as it portends to, perhaps, loan growth in the future. But in the meantime, we did add some securities, and I'll let Rick talk about that.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's a little bit -- I wouldn't get too caught up in the size of the growth in the individual quarter. If you look back, we had a substantial -- most of that growth occurred -- actually, it's the same year-over-year. What happened was swap sp
componenttext: Yes, I think it's a little bit -- I wouldn't get too caught up in the size of the growth in the individual quarter. If you look back, we had a substantial -- most of that growth occurred -- actually, it's the same year-over-year. What happened was swap spreads blew out with the European debt crisis in the second quarter and so we swapped a lot of Treasuries into swaps. And now, we're just moving that back into treasury securities as well as agency mortgage-backed securities. So most of our investment is in the agency space. We also had some forward settlement trades that we did in the second quarter, settling in the third quarter. And then, we just keep generating so much in terms of the deposit base, so we keep generating a lot of liquidity. And we're just -- this excess liquidity, we're investing. Now we're keeping it all in very short duration securities. The duration of equity of the balance sheet as a whole is still negative three to three and half years. So I want to make sure that we're asset sensitive, so when rates do increase, that we can take advantage of that.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: I think that's a very good question on the securities, and Rick's point about staying short is clearly important. You don't want to -- we've said frequently, we don't want to risk the capital of the company in a bond trade.
componenttext: I think that's a very good question on the securities, and Rick's point about staying short is clearly important. You don't want to -- we've said frequently, we don't want to risk the capital of the company in a bond trade.

componenttextpreview: Just like, it appears that the securities to total assets hovers around 20% to 25%. Are you targeting that? Or you're just really making day-to-day decisions on where's the best way to put your capital?
componenttext: Just like, it appears that the securities to total assets hovers around 20% to 25%. Are you targeting that? Or you're just really making day-to-day decisions on where's the best way to put your capital?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttextpreview: It’s really not a target. But I think if you went back in the history of the company, we've always had a tremendous ability to generate deposits more so than loans, and because of the fact that we're smaller in the credit card space than some of the lar
componenttext: It’s really not a target. But I think if you went back in the history of the company, we've always had a tremendous ability to generate deposits more so than loans, and because of the fact that we're smaller in the credit card space than some of the larger banks. And the other part is, is that we tend to securitize all of our mortgages as to putting large bulks of them on our balance sheet. So we've always been more liquid than others.

componenttext: I guess my question is, all this capital and nowhere to go. So the first part of the question that was -- what's your Tier 1 common ratio under Basel III? Or are you going under Basel III?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Well, it's hard to say what it is until we get the BlackRock interpretation. So I think we just have to wait and see where -- you can't say this, it does matter, but quite frankly, however it works out, we've got a lot of capital. So we're over any of the
componenttext: Well, it's hard to say what it is until we get the BlackRock interpretation. So I think we just have to wait and see where -- you can't say this, it does matter, but quite frankly, however it works out, we've got a lot of capital. So we're over any of the guidelines that are currently shown. And I think we want to be over them, but the real question is how far. And I think we are well over the guidelines as it appears today.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.

componenttext: How about risk-weighted assets, what's the impact of Basel III?

componenttext: It's not a meaningful issue for us at all.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: So we're really just talking about BlackRock. And what's even just a rough range?
componenttext: So we're really just talking about BlackRock. And what's even just a rough range?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: It's hard to say, because there's a number of things. One is that we're not certain that BlackRock even falls under the definition of financial institution. As you know, the rule about investing in minority interest in other financial institutions was rea
componenttext: It's hard to say, because there's a number of things. One is that we're not certain that BlackRock even falls under the definition of financial institution. As you know, the rule about investing in minority interest in other financial institutions was really proposed to affect banks investing in other banks and then re-levering the same capital. And so, BlackRock's not a leveraged institution, as you know. So it kind of doesn't fall in the category of the purpose of the rule. So we have to wait and see whether it's -- and they've not been included under Basel I or Basel II. So we have to wait and know whether it actually fits at all. And secondly, as Rick said earlier, we have an almost $2 billion reserve for taxes set up. So it clearly seems to me that it's got to be an after -tax view, because the theory is, if the stock runs down, well, if the stock runs down, we're not going to have to pay all those taxes. So that's got to be an after-tax item. And then, there's another issue that says in the rule, that it's common stock. And only 50% of our holdings at BlackRock are in common, the other in preferred. So I mean, we've got a number of things that have to be interpreted around the BlackRock, a number of which could go our way. But in any event, however it's interpreted, frankly, we've got a lot of capital, back to your initial point.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Mike, the public data points are, we have an investment of $6 billion. We got deferred taxes, which probably brings that close to $4 billion. And 1% on our ratio is $2.5 billion. And that's all public data, so you have to think about, it could be
componenttext: Yes, and Mike, the public data points are, we have an investment of $6 billion. We got deferred taxes, which probably brings that close to $4 billion. And 1% on our ratio is $2.5 billion. And that's all public data, so you have to think about, it could be anywhere from zero to maybe 1.5 points.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: And when do you think you'll hear about the BlackRock interpretation?

componenttextpreview: We'd love to hope we're going to hear between now and the end of the year, but we're not certain about that.
componenttext: We'd love to hope we're going to hear between now and the end of the year, but we're not certain about that.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, so you have excess capital. What are your priorities for using it? And what about acquisitions?
componenttext: And then lastly, so you have excess capital. What are your priorities for using it? And what about acquisitions?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Well, we'd love to use it for our customers, but it doesn't appear that the loan demand is there. And even if it is, we'd have plenty of flexibility in the balance sheet without having to change any capital ratios. Secondly, I think our shareholders deser
componenttext: Well, we'd love to use it for our customers, but it doesn't appear that the loan demand is there. And even if it is, we'd have plenty of flexibility in the balance sheet without having to change any capital ratios. Secondly, I think our shareholders deserve -- we would love to see -- we'd love to have the ability to raise the dividend. I think that would be a good thing. We also think that our shares are trading cheaply compared to what they're worth, and kind of amazes me that we do trade at multiples of book that are below some of our peers. And then, obviously, acquisitions, banks are sold, not bought. And so, for the right type of acquisition, I think we'd be interested in that as well. So those, I think, would be the priorities.

componenttextpreview: And then separately, as we think about just kind of NIM longer term, I can appreciate there's a lot of moving pieces here. But obviously, if rates stay low, asset yields are still likely to come down further. But how should we think about the funding side
componenttext: And then separately, as we think about just kind of NIM longer term, I can appreciate there's a lot of moving pieces here. But obviously, if rates stay low, asset yields are still likely to come down further. But how should we think about the funding side of things? Because you still have a lot of CDs. You have a low loan-to-deposit ratio. There's a chunk of long-term debt. So how should we think about the opportunity of pricing to funding? And how quickly and how aggressively can you bring down some of those?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Well, you're right. We do have another $7 billion of CDs that are going to mature in the fourth quarter. The average rate's about 2.2%. So right now, we're able to re-price those down 1% lower. And that's why when I said before, the drop into the fourth q
componenttext: Well, you're right. We do have another $7 billion of CDs that are going to mature in the fourth quarter. The average rate's about 2.2%. So right now, we're able to re-price those down 1% lower. And that's why when I said before, the drop into the fourth quarter is primarily due to the purchase accounting running off as opposed to our core book, which is remaining pretty flat as the benefit on deposit pricing as well as some of the security yields is funding some of what we lose on the loan side as rates remain low.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: If rates remains low, at this rate, for a long period of time, I mean, there's all kinds of economic issues. But we’ll be re-pricing liabilities for a long period to come.

companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.

componenttext: First, I guess, 3.5% reserve-to-loan ratio, pretty high among large regional banks. Where do you see that sort of coming down to? Or what range would you see that coming down to over the long term?

componenttextpreview: I think that would be guidance we'll give in the fourth quarter, Ed, as we have a better indication of what next year is going to look like. I think for the time being though, we've had two quarters of improvement in the credit statistics. I think as we g
componenttext: I think that would be guidance we'll give in the fourth quarter, Ed, as we have a better indication of what next year is going to look like. I think for the time being though, we've had two quarters of improvement in the credit statistics. I think as we get more and more confidence in that decline, as we work through that, clearly that will come lower. And obviously, it'll come down as non-performing loans come down, we'll continue to release or utilize reserves as we decrease our non-performing loan category.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: So it's reasonable to think about, at least, several quarters and sort of stop there from an outlook, but several quarters, at least, of additional reserve recapture?
componenttext: So it's reasonable to think about, at least, several quarters and sort of stop there from an outlook, but several quarters, at least, of additional reserve recapture?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: The building of reserves, obviously, is for future charge-offs. And so, you'll always see the provision peak before charge-offs peak, because you're providing for future charge-offs. I mean, even if you put on – every day, you put on a past loan, you pu
componenttext: The building of reserves, obviously, is for future charge-offs. And so, you'll always see the provision peak before charge-offs peak, because you're providing for future charge-offs. I mean, even if you put on – every day, you put on a past loan, you put on some reserves for potential future defaults. So the provisions will peak and charge-offs will peak later. So I think you're right about the continued improvement.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: And then, second question, Rick, in terms of the purchase accounting accretion, you talked about it coming down more in the fourth quarter. Subsequent to that, should we expect it to become more stable for a while? Or is there sort of a continued downward
componenttext: And then, second question, Rick, in terms of the purchase accounting accretion, you talked about it coming down more in the fourth quarter. Subsequent to that, should we expect it to become more stable for a while? Or is there sort of a continued downward trend that we should anticipate?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Well, on the loan side, clearly, over the next two to three years, you're going to see a continued downward trend on both performing and impaired. So there's no question about that. The deposit side, probably, will run its course next year. And the debt s
componenttext: Well, on the loan side, clearly, over the next two to three years, you're going to see a continued downward trend on both performing and impaired. So there's no question about that. The deposit side, probably, will run its course next year. And the debt side is going to be the next 15 years, which as you can see, is a pretty de minimus amount. So what we're expecting next quarter, Ed, is that, that scheduled number, which you had this quarter, 212, maybe that drops to $200 million, I think it was $212 million. And we're expecting the cash recoveries to be much lower than what we have in the current quarter. We had $111 million, maybe coming down to be about $50 million. So I think, the overall purchase accounting next quarter will be about in around $250 million.

componenttext: Okay, so most of the decline is on that cash recovery side?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Secondly, I guess I just wanted to understand your thought process in mapping the net interest margin against the provision as opposed to charge-offs. When you think of that, and usually when I think about a risk-adjusted margin, it's charge offs, because
componenttext: Secondly, I guess I just wanted to understand your thought process in mapping the net interest margin against the provision as opposed to charge-offs. When you think of that, and usually when I think about a risk-adjusted margin, it's charge offs, because the provision's got this kind of, little bit of a backward-looking catch-up to it, particularly at this point. And there's going to be a point at which your reserve draw downs stop and you're not going to have, I would think, not going to have a corresponding jump in net interest income. So maybe, can you talk about that a little bit, as to how you kind of thought about that process?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: The provisioning process, actually, I would suggest, is actually a little bit more forward-looking in terms of anticipating what losses we're going to incur in the future that have incurred to date. Whereas the charge-offs is actually more lagged when we
componenttext: The provisioning process, actually, I would suggest, is actually a little bit more forward-looking in terms of anticipating what losses we're going to incur in the future that have incurred to date. Whereas the charge-offs is actually more lagged when we actually work our way through it. And it's more volatile. So I don't think -- it usually doesn't give you a very good indication quarter-to-quarter. So we just think the provision is just a better balancing factor to what you can expect over time.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: When you look back in the 2004, '05 and '06 area, and we were using this as a tool to forecast future profitability, we were receiving -- people were complaining that we weren't growing our loans fast enough and other people had higher margins. And quite
componenttext: When you look back in the 2004, '05 and '06 area, and we were using this as a tool to forecast future profitability, we were receiving -- people were complaining that we weren't growing our loans fast enough and other people had higher margins. And quite frankly, we said they were taking risks that we didn't think you got paid for. Obviously, they put on substantial subprime loans, that people have big portfolios in the LBO space with leverage that came back to haunt them. And frankly, what we did, we didn't do those kinds of loans and actually didn't drive our gross margin up the way they did. And I think what happened was, our risk-adjusted margin really proved to be a good indicator of future and consistent profitability.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Konrad with KBW.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Konrad with KBW.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Just want to follow up on the rev on [ph] warranty risk. I just wonder if you guys could add a little color on where your total reserve stands now? And then just, over the past couple quarters, what the reserve and losses have been for rev on warranty?
componenttext: Just want to follow up on the rev on [ph] warranty risk. I just wonder if you guys could add a little color on where your total reserve stands now? And then just, over the past couple quarters, what the reserve and losses have been for rev on warranty?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: I'm happy to, David. In total, we've got about $290 million of reserves, and it's concentrated primarily in the mortgage company at about $150 million to $160 million. We feel pretty good about that reserve given the fact that: one, the amount of claims t
componenttext: I'm happy to, David. In total, we've got about $290 million of reserves, and it's concentrated primarily in the mortgage company at about $150 million to $160 million. We feel pretty good about that reserve given the fact that: one, the amount of claims that are being made is coming down and has been coming down, this is all related to 2008 and prior; and as well as the fact that I think we're just getting better as an organization in terms of defending the claims and what the actual risk is. So that appears to be -- we, this quarter, actually, handled some additional claims on mortgage insurance as well as the GSE's taking a harder look at OREO, and we feel we've got that reasonably well reserved. So we're pretty comfortable there. We also have the distressed asset book where we've got $100 million of reserves, and that's a combination of things. But probably, the most significant, being brokered home equity sales at National City. We're getting a little bit of pushback on that. And we just felt that appropriate to set up some reserves on that. There may be some further smaller reserves we have to add to that over time as that becomes clear, but whatever it is, it'll be a manageable number.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: And how have the losses been trending over the last couple quarters?
componenttext: And how have the losses been trending over the last couple quarters?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Coming down. Particularly in mortgage company, losses have been coming down pretty regularly, with the exception of new events like the mortgage insurers bailing out or the GSEs going back and looking at OREOs. But other than that, the basic claims have b
componenttext: Coming down. Particularly in mortgage company, losses have been coming down pretty regularly, with the exception of new events like the mortgage insurers bailing out or the GSEs going back and looking at OREOs. But other than that, the basic claims have been coming down pretty rapidly over the last few quarters.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Heather Wolf with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Heather Wolf with UBS.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: First of all, on the purchase accounting accretion, can you talk a little bit about the decline this quarter, the $376 million down to the $214 million? Is that just a result of all the loan sales that you guys have been doing? Or was there some kind of a
componenttext: First of all, on the purchase accounting accretion, can you talk a little bit about the decline this quarter, the $376 million down to the $214 million? Is that just a result of all the loan sales that you guys have been doing? Or was there some kind of a change in the assumptions behind the future cash flows?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Heather, we had made an adjustment on impaired loans in the second quarter of approximately $78 million, which didn't repeat in the third quarter. So right off the top, that's one of the items. We also made an adjustment in our purchase accounting for deb
componenttext: Heather, we had made an adjustment on impaired loans in the second quarter of approximately $78 million, which didn't repeat in the third quarter. So right off the top, that's one of the items. We also made an adjustment in our purchase accounting for debt for about $29 million. So you can see the delta on that, second to third quarter. So that's roughly over $100 million of adjustments which were made in the second we didn't expect to repeat. And then, the other decrease was that we did have some loan sales, but it was primarily in the commercial space where we sold a number of loans and we're able to drive net interest income. It came down. We had a lot of those sales in the third quarter, and what it did was it caused that scheduled NII [net interest income] to come down. But we picked that up in the recovery area.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, just a second question on deposit strategies. I guess, if rates stay where they are for an extended period of time, the spread that you're earning on some of your money market and even your lower cost CDs, is going to compress. Will the
componenttext: Got it. And then, just a second question on deposit strategies. I guess, if rates stay where they are for an extended period of time, the spread that you're earning on some of your money market and even your lower cost CDs, is going to compress. Will the strategy be to sort of keep the relationships and suffer NIM compression? Or will you be looking to maybe shrink your deposit balances a little bit by running off even further CDs than you've talked about already?

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: We, typically, would have the responsibility keeping the deposits. But I think you'll see, if the rates stay low, I think you'll see the entire industry taking their rates down and as they have in CD pricing and elsewhere, because there really isn't -- I
componenttext: We, typically, would have the responsibility keeping the deposits. But I think you'll see, if the rates stay low, I think you'll see the entire industry taking their rates down and as they have in CD pricing and elsewhere, because there really isn't -- I mean it's not a good sign to go out the yield curve and it's a -- and I'm not sure you could go out the credit curve if you wanted to so, because loan demand is so low. I mean you can always do something stupid like that, but I think you'd see the rates come down across the industry.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only place we're seeing any pressure on rates is in companies that are in need of significant liquidity funding at the moment, who may be doing more lending than the market is ready to bear at the moment. So we're seeing a little bit of pressure
componenttext: Yes, the only place we're seeing any pressure on rates is in companies that are in need of significant liquidity funding at the moment, who may be doing more lending than the market is ready to bear at the moment. So we're seeing a little bit of pressure there, but that's about it.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
companyname: The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.
componenttextpreview: There are no further questions at this time.
componenttext: There are no further questions at this time.

componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you. Well, thank you very much for joining us. We think it was an excellent quarter. We not only had a great earnings quarter, but we also accomplished a lot as a company in terms of credit conversion, building capital. And we look forward to
componenttext: Great. Thank you. Well, thank you very much for joining us. We think it was an excellent quarter. We not only had a great earnings quarter, but we also accomplished a lot as a company in terms of credit conversion, building capital. And we look forward to talking to you again soon. Thank you.

headline: PNC Financial Services Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.
